direction.raw_text: ...she gave to my family a fidelity without stint or calculation or recompense and gave to my childhood an immeasurable devotion and love".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AIBILEEN'S HOUSE - KITCHEN - NIGHT AIBILEEN, black, 53, sits at a table in a small, green kitchen. She wears a yellow dress with black piping and grips a tattered spiral notebook. Although cracked, the window behind her is crystal clear. Three framed portraits hang on the wall above her: John F. Kennedy, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and an UNKNOWN YOUNG BLACK MALE wearing thick glasses. Aibileen swallows hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was...born in 1911...on Piedmont Plantation in Cherokee County. An UNSEEN WOMAN interviews Aibileen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.C.) Did you know as a girl, growing up, that one day you'd be a maid?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am. I did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.C.) And you knew that because?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Momma was a maid. My grandmother was a house slave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (0.C.) Oh. The woman repeats Aibileen's answer slowly as she writes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.C.) (CONT'D) A...House...Slave. Uh-huh. Okay. Aibileen squeezes the notebook in her lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.C.) (CONT'D) Now, did you ever dream of being something else? Aibileen gulps. She doesn't answer. The room is quiet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.C.) (CONT'D) Well then, what's it feel like, to raise a white child when your own child's at home...being looked after by somebody else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Aibileen's hand trembles as she sips from a glass of water. She glances sadly up to the picture of the young black male.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I done raised seventeen kids in my life. Lookin' after white babies, that's what I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEEFOLT HOME - MAE MOBLEY'S ROOM - MORNING MAE MOBLEY LEEFOLT, 2 1/2 years old, lies in a crib, crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: enters. Her dark black skin contrasts angelically with a brilliant white work dress, white panty hose and shoes
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I know how to get them babies asleep, stop cryin' and go in the toilet bowl before they mommas even get outta bed in the mornin.' Aibileen lifts Mae Mobley out of her crib and pulls her into her expansive bosom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) (CONT'D) Babies like fat. They like big fat legs too. That I know. Aibileen sits with Mae Mobley in a rocking chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O) (CONT'D) I work from eight to four, six days a week. Ninety-five cents an hour comes to a hundred seventy-two dollars ever month. I do all the cooking, cleaning, washing, ironing and grocery shopping, but mostly, I take care a baby girl...And law, I worry she gone be fat. Ain't gonna be no beauty queen either. Mae Mobley reaches up and touches Aibileen's face. Aibileen kisses her and whispers in her ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You is kind. You is smart. You is important. Mae Mobley's mother, ELIZABETH LEEFOLT, 21 and lanky, enters wearing a green dress very much under construction. Pins and double-stick tape hold it all together. Elizabeth has pointed features and a nest of teased, brittle hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen, bridge club's in an hour! Did you finish the chicken salad?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, and Hilly's deviled eggs. No paprika! Elizabeth rotates around like the Tin Man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does this dress look homemade?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I reckon when you finish, it won't. Elizabeth exits with her pinned hemline sloping at a good twenty degree angle. Aibileen shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) (CONT'D) Miss Leefolt still don't pick Baby Girl up but once a day. The birthin' blues had got holt a Miss Leefolt pretty hard. I done seen it happen plenty a times...once babies start havin' they own babies. And the young white ladies of Jackson...Oh, law, they was havin' some babies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A smoking RECEPTIONIST, 50, leads EUGENIA "SKEETER" PHELAN, 23, across a smoke-filled news office. Even the light bulbs have yellowed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) But, not Miss Skeeter... Skeeter has very frizzy blond hair cut short above her shoulders. She carries a red satchel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) (CONT'D) No babies...No man...And not lookin'. She wears flats, careful not to add more than a centimeter to her towering height. Dressed well, Skeeter tugs on her unfamiliar attire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLACKLY'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS The receptionist and Skeeter enter the office of MR. HAROLD BLACKLY, 68. He has greased, grey hair and the face of a mean man. Smoke pours into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLACKLY Shut the Goddamn door! He snaps his fingers over a chair. Skeeter sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLACKLY (CONT'D) They announced last week cigarettes'll kill you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Mr. Blackly pours a pack of nuts into his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLACKLY (CONT'D) (CHEWING) Okay, let's see what you got. Skeeter quickly hands Mr. Blackly a resume. He skims it over, marking it violently with a red pen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLACKLY (CONT'D) "Murrah High Editor, Ole Miss Rebel Rouser Editor, double major, Junior League editor...Damn girl, didn't you have any fun?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that...important? Mr. Blackly sighs, hands the resume back to Skeeter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLACKLY You got any references? Skeeter nods slowly. She takes a deep breath and pulls a letter out of her satchel. She hands it to Mr. Blackly. Mr. Blackly snatches the letter and reads it quickly, mouthing the words as he does. He drops the letter on his desk, and looks to Skeeter, flabbergasted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLACKLY (CONT'D) That...is a rejection letter. Skeeter's face flushes hot and quick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not exactly. Missus Stein-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLACKLY -STEIN?! Missus who? Skeeter points toward the letterhead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elaine Stein, Senior Editor at Harper and Row Publishing. In New York. I'm going to be a serious writer, Mr. Blackly. So, when I applied to Harper and Row, Missus
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLACKLY -She told you "no."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Until I gain some experience, Mr. Blackly! See, it says it right there at the end. "Great potential...Gain some experience and please apply again." Mr. Blackly pours the rest of the peanuts in his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLACKLY Oh, Christ...I guess you'll do. Can you clean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clean? Mr. Blackly sees cigarette smoke bleeding under his door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLACKLY Clean! Mr. Blackly pulls up a box filled with letters and newspapers. He slams it down in front of Skeeter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLACKLY (CONT'D) Miss Myrna's gone shit-house crazy on us, drunk hair spray or something. Read her past columns and all these letters. Answer them just like she did, nobody'll know the damn difference. Skeeter forces a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLACKLY (CONT'D) You know who Miss Myrna is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I read her articles all the time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLACKLY Articles? Ha! It's a cleaning advice column, Miss Phelan. Eight bucks a week. Copy due Thursday. Mr. Blackly picks up the phone and starts yelling at someone. Skeeter excitedly grabs the box of letters and leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: white and hefty, sits on a closed toilet seat in a well-appointed bathroom. She's covered in red plaid and bows and has a round face topped by a perfect beehive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Momma! We're late for bridge! Hilly carefully rolls toilet paper out from its holder. She raises a pencil and places the tiniest dot imaginable on the first and second sheets of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Miss Hilly was the first of the babies to have a baby. And it must a come out of her like the eleventh commandment. `Cause once Miss Hilly had a baby, ever girl at the bridge table wanted one too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She carefully rolls the paper back up in the roll.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny! Go get Momma!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: black, plump and in uniform, rolls her eyes beneath a crystal chandelier. She shouts up the mahogany stairwell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Missus Walters?! You need help coming down?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: passes quietly behind Minny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm down! Minny jumps with a yelp, spins around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Been down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gone give me a heart attack! Missus Walters ambles toward the closet door. Minny quickly tries to turn her toward the front door. Missus Walters resists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny, I'm getting my coat. Missus Walters opens the closet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's ninety degrees out there, Missus Walters. Missus Walters pulls out a red, wool coat with cheetah print collar. The early stages of Alzheimer's have appeared, but Missus Walters is still quite proud at eighty percent capacity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Once Missus Walters' arteries went hard, Miss Hilly moved her and Minny in with her. Fired the maid she had just to make room. See, Minny about the best cook in Mississippi, and Miss Hilly wanted her. Hilly's approach is marked by the whishing sound of her plaid, fat thighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She nonchalantly grabs the coat from her mother and carries it out the door. Minny and Missus Walters follow. Minny carries a chocolate pie. Hilly barks over her shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny, William took Billy out for ice cream. So, hurry back and get Billy down for his nap. No dilly dallying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am. Minny raises the pie behind Hilly's beehive, dreaming of smashing it into her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Minny my best friend. A old lady like me lucky to have her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEEFOLT HOME - BATHROOM- SAME DAY Aibileen kneels next to Mae Mobley who sits on a small children's training toilet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) It's a tricky thing...you try to make a baby go in the toilet bowl before it's time. If theys can't get the hang of it, theys get to thinking low a theyselves. Mae Mobley sticks her lip out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You drunk up two glasses a grape juice, I know you got to tee-tee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nooo. Mae Mobley shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I give you a cookie if you go. Tee-tee immediately sprinkles into the bowl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mae Mobley! You going! Aibileen and Mae Mobley laugh excitedly as Elizabeth storms into the bathroom in her finished dress. The hemline now slants in the other direction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen, the girls are pulling up, and the table isn't set!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mae Mobley go, Momma!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get in your room! Right now! Mae Mobley rises behind Aibileen's leg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I sorry. Elizabeth reaches down and scoops up Mae Mobley like a sack of potatoes. Mae Mobley looks to Aibileen over her mother's shoulder, her eyes have welled up. Aibileen mouths "I love you" and blows her a kiss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEEFOLT HOME - DINING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER The Leefolt's small, wood paneled, two bedroom "ranch" is destined to become income property one day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: early 20s, and Elizabeth hover around two collapsible card tables arranged in the living room. Aibileen methodically arranges grapes on a platter of chicken salad resting on Elizabeth's dining table. The table has a small L-SHAPED CRACK in the middle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I lost my own boy, Treelore, right before I started waitin' on the Leefolts... Elizabeth glances anxiously to the dining table then catches eyes with Aibileen, nodding ever so slightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen carefully slides the platter over the L-SHAPED CRACK making sure it's hidden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) (CONT'D) After Treelore died, a bitter seed was planted inside a me. And I just didn't feel so accepting anymore. Hilly enters the front door holding Missus Walters coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, girls!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Hilly! Minny follows behind holding the pie and Missus Walters' arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (over her shoulder) Put Momma in a chair before she breaks a hip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not deaf yet, Hilly. Minny spies Aibileen in the corner and gives her a "here we go" look as she lowers Missus Walters into a chair. Hilly approaches Aibileen with the coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen, I want you to have this coat. It's too big for Momma now and it's way too expensive to put in the coat drive. Hilly extends the coat with a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All yours. Aibileen takes the coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Miss Hilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on. Try it on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEEFOLT HOME - KITCHEN - MOMENTS LATER Minny plows through the swing door and reaches for Hilly's deviled eggs. Aibileen rushes in behind her wearing the cheetah collared coat. The sleeves are about a foot too short.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold on! Those are Miss Hilly's. Aibileen pulls another plate of eggs out of the fridge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gots to have paprika on `em. Minny takes an egg. It disappears in a single bite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive me, Lord, but I'm gonna have to kill that woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Aibileen removes the coat and lays it over a chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watch yo mouth, Minny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks like a walking Christmas present with all them bows. Aibileen shakes with silent laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And, now she gone to puttin' pencil marks on the toilet paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, law! Did she?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh-hum. But, I carry paper in from my own damn house. That fool don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEEFOLT HOME - LIVING ROOM - SAME TIME Elizabeth and Hilly cackle with a group of girls as Missus Walters sits on the couch watching "Guiding Light." Skeeter suddenly rushes through the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, girls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Skeeter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: approaches and hugs Skeeter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if it isn't Long-Haul- Skeeter. We didn't think you'd ever leave Ole Miss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it's supposed to take four years, Jolene. Skeeter spins around to Hilly and Elizabeth with a sigh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry I'm late. I had to stop by the cleaners and pick up my black dress. Hilly and Elizabeth look at Skeeter with concern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About supper club tonight...Honey, Stuart had to cancel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again? Hilly places her hand on Skeeter's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can't get off the rig, Skeeter. It's offshore! Stuart is a very successful oil man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm starting to think this Stuart is a figment of your imagination.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Raleigh called his cousin down in Hattiesburg. He'll drive up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cousin with one eye?! Elizabeth nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess his black patch will match my dress. Just forget it. Skeeter storms off. Hilly glares at Elizabeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One eye?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEEFOLT HOME - LIVING ROOM - LATER THE SAME DAY Aibileen clears the dining table as bridge begins. Hilly, Elizabeth and Skeeter sit with Jolene. Skeeter takes a deep breath and belts out her news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got a job today... at The Jackson Journal! Everyone looks at Skeeter as if she just threw up on herself. Finally, Hilly pats Skeeter on the leg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They'd be a fool not to hire you. Jolene raises her glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To Skeeter...and her job. Last stop `til marriage. Hilly kicks Jolene under the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Miss Myrna column. Have y'all read it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, no! But, I bet the poor girls without any help, in South Jackson, read it like the King James. Everyone laughs. Skeeter's forehead crinkles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elizabeth, would you mind if I talk to Aibileen? To help me answer some of the letters? Just until I get a knack for it. Aibileen clears dishes as if she hasn't heard a thing. Elizabeth gets very still.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen? My Aibileen? What can't you just get Constantine to help you? Skeeter looks to her lap and shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Constantine...quit us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?! Oh, my gosh! Skeeter nods her head sadly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so sorry, Skeeter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I really don't want to talk about it. Okay? The girls nod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyway...I don't know how to answer these letters. Elizabeth looks to Aibileen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well...I mean as long as it doesn't interfere with her work. A phone rings. Elizabeth nods to Aibileen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEEFOLT HOME - KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS Aibileen rushes in the kitchen and answers the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leefolt residence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON: Pink, fuzzy slippers anchoring bare, sexy legs stand on a black and white check floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.C.) Ah-hem. Hello, is Elizabeth in? Rising up a slim torso, sizeable cleavage bursts out of a pink robe's collar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She having bridge club right now. May I take a message?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: peroxide blonde, stands in all her country girl glory. She speaks with a thick, unrefined, Southern accent, mired in insecurity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please tell her Celia Foote called again. I'll call back tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am. Celia nervously twists herself around in the phone cord.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah-hem. Miss? "Miss" strikes Aibileen as very odd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm looking for some help at my house. You know any maids looking?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, ma'am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Celia Foote. Emerson 6-8-4. Bye, now. Celia hands up the phone with a frown and sips from a coca- cola bottle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEEFOLT HOME - LIVING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER Aibileen enters the living room with a coffee pot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who was that on the phone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Celia Foote called again. Elizabeth leans over and touches Hilly's arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've never called her back, Hilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She can't take a hint, can she?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's Celia Foote?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That tacky girl Johnny married.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Girl? I heard she's twenty-eight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my God!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh-hmm, worked concessions at a LSU game and sold him a hotdog. And, boy, he got a whole lot more. All the girls laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could have been you, Hilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And live thirty minutes outside of town? Anyway, I ran into her at the beauty parlor, and she had the nerve to ask if she could help with the children's benefit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aren't we taking non-members? The benefit's gotten so big.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, but we're not telling her. Everyone laughs but Skeeter. Aibileen pours Skeeter a cup of coffee. Skeeter looks up decidedly and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Aibileen. Hilly begins squirming in her seat, obviously making a point. Elizabeth leans over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Hilly, I wish you'd just go use the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah-hem. I'm fine. Missus Walters shouts out from the sofa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's upset cause the nigra uses the guest bath, and so do we. Elizabeth turns to Aibileen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen, go check on Mae Mobley. Aibileen disappears. Elizabeth leans into Hilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just go use mine and Raleigh's. Hilly hiss-whispers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If Aibileen uses the guest bathroom, I'm sure she uses yours too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! Aibileen turns the corner in the hall and stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wouldn't you rather them take their business outside? Skeeter sees a reflection of Aibileen listening off of a picture in the hall. Skeeter tries to change the subject.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did y'all see the cover of "Life" this week? Jackie's never looked
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -Tell Raleigh every penny he spends on a colored's bathroom, he'll get back in spades when y'all sell. It's just plain dangerous. Everybody knows they carry different diseases than we do. I double. Elizabeth takes a puff of her cigarette and fidgets with her cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't ask Raleigh until tax season. But, it would be nice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why I've drafted The Home Help Sanitation Initiative.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "The Home"...the what?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As a disease preventative bill that requires every white home to have a separate bathroom for the colored help. I've even notified the Surgeon General of Mississippi. I'll pass. Skeeter again glances at Aibileen. Their eyes meet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe we ought to just build you a bathroom outside, Hilly. The room grows eerily quiet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You ought not to joke about the colored situation. Hilly leans in toward Skeeter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll do whatever it takes to protect our town. Your lead, Jolene. Jolene suddenly looks to a wall clock. She jumps up and throws her cards to the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to skedaddle! Gotta get over to the station! (EXCITEDLY) Daddy's letting me do the weather tonight!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Celia delicately prunes two rosebushes. Her long pink fingernails wrap easily around a pair of sheers. As Celia stands back to admire her work, We widen to see the Foote estate. Ancient oaks dripping in Spanish moss surround a perfectly manicured lawn. "Tara" pales in comparison. Oddly, the two rosebushes have been planted in the center of the lawn, jeopardizing the Antebellum Feng Shui.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Now, Miss Celia had her a man. `Bout the best lookin' man in all of Mississippi. But, no baby and no friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Celia's ridiculously handsome husband, sneaks up behind her as he removes his jacket and tie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roses look like weeds next to you. Celia turns with a yelp. She slaps him playfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Johnny, you scared the daylights out of me! Johnny begins kissing her neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're home early. Celia pushes him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Johnny, I can't get any of your old friends from school to call me back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, who cares, honey. We got all we need right here. Johnny kisses her again and lowers her to the grass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Johnny, honestly!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doctor's orders. Johnny starts kissing Celia's breasts. She becomes uneasy and rolls out from under him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what's taking us so long. I'm sorry. Johnny brushes hair from Celia's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, we've never done it in the yard. Maybe that's the trick. Celia seductively bites her lower lip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watch my hair. Johnny's hand slides up her thigh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEEFOLT HOME - KITCHEN - LATER THAT DAY Bridge over, Skeeter smokes while watching through a window as Minny arrives in Hilly's car. Skeeter blows smoke toward Hilly and Elizabeth saying good-bye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A sermon plays over an old AM radio nestled between canisters of sugar and flour. Aibileen enters with a stack of dirty coffee cups.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen? Aibileen becomes nervous at the sight of Skeeter alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had hoped to ask you myself if you could help me with the "Miss Myrna" letters...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So...Would you help me? Aibileen nods and looks out to Elizabeth on the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Myrna gets it wrong lotta times. Be good to get it right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Aibileen. I plan on splitting the pay with you, too. Aibileen doesn't respond. She grabs a basket of rolls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen...all that talk in there today. Hilly's talk I mean...I'm sorry you had to hear that. Aibileen quickly turns her back to Skeeter. A gospel choir begins singing on the radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that Preacher Green's sermon on the radio?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am, it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That reminds me so much of my maid growing up. Aibileen starts wiping down a serving tray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Constantine and me...were in church circle together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Skeeter turns to Aibileen as she puts out her cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She loved me like you love Mae Mobley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am. Skeeter moves closer to Aibileen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen? How could she just quit like that? Aibileen stops wiping and looks up to Skeeter...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. When I got home from school last week, Momma said she had quit. Back in March to go live with her people up in Chicago. She didn't leave me a note or anything. Aibileen turns and resumes wiping the tray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could you do that to Mae Mobley? Aibileen slowly turns back to Skeeter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, ma'am. I couldn't...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have an address for her or anything? Aibileen shrugs her shoulders, reeling it all back in. Just then, Elizabeth walks into the kitchen holding papers stapled together. She looks between Aibileen and Skeeter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. Did I interrupt something? Skeeter and Aibileen shake their heads. Elizabeth hands Skeeter the papers. Home Help Sanitation Initiative is written on the cover.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hilly wants this put in the League newsletter. Skeeter nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen, I'll drop by at ten tomorrow to get started on Miss Myrna. Elizabeth looks at Aibileen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tomorrow is silver polishing day, so y'all make it quick, okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter speeds down a country road lined with ancient oak trees in a white Cadillac.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I knew I had said too much to Miss Skeeter, but Constantine's story weren't mine to tell. Some things a girl shouldn't have to know about her own mother. Her frizzy hair swirls about as she passes a truck full of cotton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter looks ahead and sees an OLDER BLACK WOMAN walking with a LITTLE BLONDE GIRL, 6. They hold hands. The black woman smiles and waves as Skeeter passes. When Skeeter looks in her rear view mirror, they're gone. Skeeter suddenly stops the car just short of an intersecting gravel road. Skeeter slowly turns down the old road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter's car pulls into the overgrown yard of an old shack with a rusted-out tin roof. Two clapboard rooms are separated by an open breezeway. The front door is cracked opened. Skeeter gets out and walks toward Constantine's home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter enters to find only a small bed, dresser, table, rocking chair and a wood burning stove. Past intruders have long since taken anything of value.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . As Skeeter approaches Constantine's bed, an OPOSSUM scurries out from underneath. Skeeter screams as the opossum runs out the door. Her eyes suddenly catch something. Lying on the bed is an OLD CORN PIPE. Skeeter picks it up and brings it to her face. Her eyes begin to well up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter pulls in front of a grand antebellum home and parks to the side of her family's graveyard. Skeeter carries her black dress up the stairs of a covered porch. An old black man with white hair, JAMESO, 70, tightens a porch swing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Jameso.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Miss Eugenia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter walks through the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Momma! If the Smithsonian had wished to assemble the perfect antebellum home, Skeeter would be standing in it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PHELAN HOME - PARENTS' BEDROOM - MOMENTS LATER Skeeter enters and looks around curiously at an ARRAY OF WIGS resting atop a dresser.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Momma? Skeeter's mother, CHARLOTTE BOUDREAU CANTELLE PHELAN, 50, glides into the room wearing a wig. Her floral print dress has a gazillion perfectly pressed pleats. Charlotte turns to a mirror and adjusts an auburn-colored, `pixie' cut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this a little too young?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a little too everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Charlotte removes the wig with a sigh. Only now do we realize her decision to wear wigs isn't elective. Thinning hair detracts from her perfectly made up face. Charlotte puts on a classic bouffant/flip in dark brown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Much better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your daddy bought me this dress in `58.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom, I want to ask you about
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -Right after Ole Miss won the Sugar Bowl. Charlotte unzips the dress and takes it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, you try it on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What really happened? Charlotte winces with pain and grasps her stomach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you...she went to live with her people in Chicago...Now, Skeeter, your mother is dying, and she wants to see you in this dress. Charlotte stands in her slip and bra holding the dress. Skeeter begins taking off her clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How could she just take off without telling me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told her not to write you. I didn't want you upset in the middle of final exams. Honey, we were just a job to her. With them it's all about money...Did I tell you Fanny Peatrow got engaged? After she got that teller job, her mother said she was just swimming in proposals.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good for "Fat Fanny Peatrow." She lowers the dress over Skeeter's head and zips it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This looks precious on you! Four years ago my daughter went off to college, and what did she come home with?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A diploma. A pretty piece of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hilly and Elizabeth have such lovely children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They dropped out of college to become housewives, Mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If only you'd show a little gumption, Eugenia...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I did get a job today.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Writing...for The Jackson Journal. Charlotte plumps up the dress around Skeeter's behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great. You can write my obituary. "Charlotte Phelan dead. Her daughter still single."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Momma, would it really be so terrible if I never met a husband? With that, Charlotte grabs Skeeter's hand and takes her to a love seat. They sit. This is serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need to...ask you something, Skeeter. I read the other day about how some girls...get unbalanced, start thinking these...well, unnatural thoughts. Charlotte begins to twist the handkerchief she holds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you...do you...find men attractive? Are you having unnatural thoughts about... Charlotte shuts her eyes tight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Girls or...or women?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my God!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because, this article says there's a cure, a special root tea. Skeeter jumps up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother, I want to be with girls as much as you wanna be with Jameso.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eugenia! Skeeter storms out of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carlton's bringing Rebecca to dinner. Try to look presentable!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Phelan dining room is lit solely by candles. The Phelan's new maid, PASCAGOLUA, 40, rolls a cart of casseroles around the table. Charlotte sits at the head of the table. She's having a bowl of broth. Skeeter sits next to her Father, ROBERT PHELAN, 60. Skeeter's brother, CARLTON, 25, sits next to his fiance,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . They're perfectly groomed with Hollywood good looks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell do you know about cleaning a house, Skeeter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a start, Carlton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you wanted to write books.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave your sister alone, Son. I'm proud of you, Sweetheart. Charlotte scoops up some broth with a spoon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, the irony of it all. Givin' advice on how to keep up a home when she... Charlotte's spoon goes in her mouth. Pascagolua tries to scoop some sort of casserole covered in almonds onto Skeeter's plate. Skeeter stops her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh! No, Pascagolua! You couldn't have known this...But, see, I'm allergic to almonds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, Miss Eugenia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Last time I had an almond, I stopped liking men. Charlotte glares at Skeeter. Carlton lets out a chuckle. Rebecca is mortified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my Lord.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's okay, Rebecca. They have a special root tea now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have pushed it, Young Lady! Pascagolua scurries off. Skeeter turns to her father...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daddy, what happened to Constantine? The room grows silent. Carlton looks down to his plate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah...well, Constantine went to live with her family. People move on, Skeeter. But I do wish she'd stayed down here with us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't believe you. Skeeter looks to her mother who immediately busies herself with scooping up more broth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother, did you...fire her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wouldn't understand. Not until you've hired help of your own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She raised me! Charlotte slaps the table and stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! Skeeter's eyes fill with tears...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She worked here for twenty-nine years. Charlotte presses both hands to her stomach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was a colored thing, and I've put it behind me. Charlotte passes behind Rebecca and kisses her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, Rebecca. My daughter has upset my cancerous ulcers. As Charlotte leaves the room, Rebecca looks at Skeeter like she's the worst person on earth. Skeeter gets up and storms off into the entry foyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter, 13 and lanky, wears a party dress. Despite a tight bun, her strong-willed hair has started to frizz. Skeeter's father and brother race down the stairs with suitcases. Carlton wears a varsity sweater.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good luck down there, Carlton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have fun at the dance, Skeeter Legs. Robert and Carlton race outside as Charlotte enters, healthy and glowing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eugenia! You've grown another inch since breakfast. Go put on a dress that fits before that boy and his daddy come pick you up. A horn blows. Charlotte kisses Skeeter on the cheek and then looks over to CONSTANTINE, 50.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Constantine stands tall. Her skin is black as night. Her eyes have a striking honey colored hue to them. She wears a white sleeping gown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pray Carlton doesn't like LSU, Constantine. It's so far. It might be the last we see of him. The horn blows again. Charlotte is out the door. Skeeter turns to Constantine who is all smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gone be just you and me all weekend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter sits at a picnic table smoking a cigarette. Constantine smokes tobacco out of a corn pipe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just couldn't tell her I didn't get asked to the dance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some things we should just keep to ourselves. Skeeter looks down to her long, bony legs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm already taller than the boys' basketball coach. How tall are you, Constantine?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm five-thirteen, so quit feeling sorry for yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Momma was third runner up in the Miss South Carolina pageant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Miss" what? Shoot, Child! You gone be "Miss Something Better." Constantine grabs Skeeter's hand and presses her thumb firmly to her palm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now you listen. Your momma didn't pick her life. It pick her, and she done even know it. You gone do something big with yours. Bigger than your momma or your brother. Constantine lets go of Skeeter's palm and wipes a tear from her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about you? What did you want to be, Constantine? Constantine laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Child! We don't get to pick. This pick us, and that just how it is. Tight on Skeeter's face as Constantine gives her a big hug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter lies in bed staring holes into the ceiling as a rooster announces the morning. A sudden revelation washes over her. In a flash, Skeeter is out of bed and running down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pascagoula tends to a skillet full of eggs next to a black and white TV resting on the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Jolene French attempts to deliver the weather on WLBT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sunny skies and a high of ninety- eight today with ninety-nine percent humidity. There's a slight chance of afternoon showers so y'all carry an umbrella. Jolene pivots to camera, lowers her chin and smiles. Skeeter runs past Pascagoula with a phone and disappears inside the pantry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hard but stylish, talks on the phone in a large corner office. She lights a cigarette and swivels her chair toward the Manhattan skyline.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What gave you this idea, Miss Phelan? I'm...curious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: TRY - SAME TIME Skeeter sits on a huge sack of flour. A millennium's supply of can goods fills the shelves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was...well, I was raised by a colored woman. I've seen how simple it can be and...well, how complex it can be, too...between the families and the help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Continue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to write something from the point of view of the help. These colored women raise white children, and then twenty years later those children become the employer. It's that irony, Miss Stein, that we love them and they love us yet...we don't even let them use the toilet in the house. Miss Stein's swivels her chair back around and sits up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Margaret Mitchell glorified the mammy figure who dedicates her whole life to a white family but no one...ever asked Mammy how she felt about it. There is both undisguised hate for white women and an inexplicable love, but nobody ever talks about it down here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, a side to this never before heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes! Charlotte knocks on the pantry door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.C.) Skeeter, who are you talking to in there? Skeeter covers the mouth piece and opens the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go! Away! Skeeter slams the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, yes, their side of the story. Skeeter leans back against the shelves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who was that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother. She just dropped by to-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, no maid in her right mind would ever tell you the truth. That's a hell of a risk in a place like Jackson, Mississippi. I watched them try to integrate your bus station on the news. Oy! They jammed fifty-five Negroes in a jail built for four. Skeeter panics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I already have a maid. Skeeter can't believe what just came out of her mouth. Miss Stein rises and sits on the edge of her desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really? A negro maid has already agreed to talk to you? Skeeter blinks hard. No turning back now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well...I suppose I could read what you come up with. The book biz could use a little rattling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd do that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm saying I'll let you know if it's even worth pursuing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, thank you, Miss Stein!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And for God's sake, you're a twenty- four-year-old educated woman. Go get an apartment. She hangs up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEEFOLT HOME - KITCHEN - LATER THAT DAY Skeeter sits across the table from Aibileen, reading the `Miss Myrna' letters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Outside, winds howl, and the sky grows dark. Jolene's forecast appears to be a bit off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Dear Miss Myrna, How do I remove the rings from my fat, slovenly husband's shirt collar when he is such a pig and sweats like one too..."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which one she want a get rid of? Them rings or the husband? Skeeter chuckles and shrugs her shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell her a vinegar and Pine-Sol soak. Then let it set in the sun a bit. Skeeter writes this down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bout an hour. Let it dry. Skeeter keeps writing. Aibileen notices something outside. Hilly walks into the Leefolt backyard with her son, BILLY, 3, perched on her hip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 30s, follows holding a set of plans. Skeeter turns to the open window. It's already started to sprinkle outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Build it just like the one at my house, right against the garage. The contractor nods. Lightning strikes, thunder cracks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, mercy! Hilly is off and running with Billy. Skeeter seizes the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen, do you ever wish you could...change things? Aibileen turns slowly from the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean, all that talk yesterday and now with what Hilly's up to. Aibileen's eyes fall to the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everthing's fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My momma fired Constantine. Thank you for telling me that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never tolt you that! Aibileen jumps up as another crack of thunder sounds out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen, I have an idea...Something I want to write about...But I need your help. Skeeter rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to interview you...about what it is like to work as a maid. Aibileen stops at the refrigerator, gripping the life out of its handle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to do a book of interviews about working for white families. Show what it's like to work for, say...Elizabeth. Aibileen begins to perspire. She grabs the counter to steady herself, then moves toward her chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what'd happen to me if Miss Leefolt knew I was tellin' stories on her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was thinking we wouldn't tell her. The other maids will have to keep it secret, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Other maids?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was hoping to get four or five. To really show what it's like in Jackson. To see what y'all get paid, the babies, the bathrooms, the good and the bad. Aibileen shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They set my cousin Shinelle's car on fire just cause she went down to the voting station.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A book has never been written like this, Aibileen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: `Cause they's a reason. I do this with you, I might as well burn my own house down. Bam! The front door slams shut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEEFOLT HOME (INTERCUT) - LIVING ROOM - SAME TIME Soaking wet, Elizabeth and her husband, RALEIGH, 25, stand toe to toe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I put up with the new clothes and all the damn trips to New Orleans, but this takes the goddamn cake!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'll confuse Mae Mobley if she sees Aibileen going inside. And we can't risk her health.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen hears Mae Mobley crying, but she is frozen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hilly spoke to the Surgeon General! She also said it'll add value to our home!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great! Mae Mobley can just go to college in that bathroom, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey, Hilly's covering the cost...and said you can just do William's taxes to pay her back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't take orders from the Holbrooks!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEEFOLT HOME - KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS Raleigh storms in and is surprised to see Skeeter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter? How you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fix me a sandwich, Aibileen. Raleigh storms out as Elizabeth charges into the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen, Mae Mobley's crying her eyes out! Aibileen runs off. Elizabeth sees Skeeter and tries to compose herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter...Hello. I'm sorry but I think it's best if you leave now. Skeeter gathers her things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And...I don't think this Miss Myrna thing is gonna work out with Aibileen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The storm has escalated. The Holbrook house is without power. Hilly runs around lighting candles. Missus Walters lies on the couch while Minny fans her with a newspaper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're making it a lot hotter flapping your arm like that. Minny stops and begins squirming with discomfort. Missus Walters notices her looking out to the garage bathroom. Lightning strikes. Leaves blow across the yard. Hilly plops down in a chair with a candle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That should do it. Minny, go get me and Momma some iced tea. Minny hesitates. She gulps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh...Miss Hilly?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never mind. As Minny turns, Missus Walters calls out to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You go on ahead and use the guest bath, Minny. It's okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, for crying out loud. It's just a little rain. She can go get an umbrella up in William's Study!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe she was working for me before you dragged us both here. Minny looks outside just as wind slams an aluminum lawn chair against the garage bathroom. Boom! Another crash of thunder. Large hail stones begin falling in the yard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm gone get your tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny sneaks into the guest bath with a candle and shuts the door. She carefully lowers the seat and sits. Relief spreads across her face. There's a knock on the door. She freezes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.C.) Minny? Minny panics, staying completely quiet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hilly leans into the bathroom door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: are you in there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you sitting down? Minny gets up quickly and flushes the toilet. Hilly beats on the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: GET OFF OF MY TOILET!!! Outside the house, an eerie, groaning sound, much like a freight train, intensifies. The top of a huge tree snaps off and falls against the house, shattering a window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Minny crouches down and covers her head. A draft sucks the candle's flame toward the bottom of the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEEFOLT HOME - MAE MOBLEY'S ROOM - MOMENTS LATER Aibileen sits with Mae Mobley against an interior wall, holding a mattress on top of them and humming in her ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) On top a Minny losin' her tenth job, eighteen people died in Jackson that day. Ten white. Eight black.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter stands in her backyard facing Jackson. Cool winds head toward the dark, swirling horizon. In the distance, lightning strikes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Celia leans on the porch railing, gazing helplessly as the relentless hail storm pummels her two rosebushes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) God don't pay no mind to color or class once he sets a tornado loose. Within seconds, the rose blossoms are gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BATHROOM/BACKYARD (INTERCUT) - THREE MONTHS LATER Aibileen uses the newly completed bathroom Hilly has built in the garage. The walls consist of unpainted plywood with a small window hugging the ceiling. Beads of sweat glisten on Aibileen's forehead under a single bulb hanging above.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Soon after, that bitter seed inside of me had sprout and was growing fast... Well into her second pregnancy, Elizabeth exits the house with Mae Mobley at her side. She wears an awful, homemade maternity dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hurry, Aibileen. Mae Mobley's up, and I'm off to the doctor. Aibileen reaches behind and flushes the toilet. Mae Mobley gets excited and points to the garage bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibee bafroom, Momma! Mae Mobley walks toward the bathroom and calls out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibee? Elizabeth grabs her and forces her down on the back step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be right there, Baby Girl. Aibileen pulls up her panty-hose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen waits with YULE MAY, 45, as well as other maids and black males at a bus stop. Yule May is tall, pretty and graceful. Her hair is pulled tightly into a bun. Skeeter walks down the sidewalk toward them. She and Aibileen catch eyes. Skeeter waves. Yule May inches away from Aibileen. One BLACK MAN in particular looks with concern as Skeeter walks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Afternoon, Aibileen. Aibileen nods nervously, looking at the other domestics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I talk to you? A bus pulls up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got some "Miss Myrna" questions for me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Yule May and others board. Skeeter grabs Aibileen's arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please. Aibileen signals to Yule May to go on ahead without her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am. The bus pulls away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please let me interview you. I know it's scary, but I really believe this has to be done. We'll be careful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This already ain't careful, Miss Skeeter. You not knowing that is what scares me most. I'm sorry. Skeeter hands Aibileen a piece of paper with her phone number written on it. Aibileen turns and walks off down the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dark outside, Aibileen approaches another, more integrated bus stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I know pretty well what happens if the white ladies found out we was writing about them. Womens, they ain't like men. Women don`t beat you with a stick. Naw, they like to keep they hands clean. Got a shiny set a tools they use, sharp as witches' fingernails. As Aibileen ambles toward a bench, TWO WHITE WOMEN in nurse uniforms push in front of her and sit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter sits at a long table surrounded by books piled high as if to provide a shield of sorts. Lying before her, is an old, thin, onionskin booklet curling at the edges. It's titled: "Compilation of Jim Crow Laws of the South" Skeeter opens the booklet and begins reading.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Any person printing, publishing or circulating written matter urging for public acceptance of social equality between whites and negroes is subject to imprisonment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AIBILEEN'S HOME - KITCHEN - NIGHT Aibileen sits at a table wearing a nightgown. She carefully combs and styles her wig for work in the morning. Her real hair is bound tightly in dozens of tightly bound nubs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The rotary wall phone rings. Aibileen hangs the wig on her chair and answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny is hysterical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Aibileen! I went and did it now! Minny wraps a hand up in the phone cord.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Hilly been tellin' everbody in town I stole a candelabra! That's why I can't get no job.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everbody know you honest, Minny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, but I got her back...I did something awful, Aibileen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What you did?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny stands on Hilly's porch holding a chocolate pie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) I cain't tell! I ain't tellin' nobody! I done a terrible awful thing to that woman. And now she knows what I did! Hilly answers the door and snarls at Minny. Minny presents the pie and says "I am sorry." Hilly waves Minny inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She got what she deserve, Aibileen. But, now I ain't gone never get no work again...Leroy gone kill me. Minny's husband, LEROY, 40, approaches behind Minny. Minny slowly turns...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen hears a loud slap and Minny's phone dropping to the floor. Yelling and screaming follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny! She can't bear to listen and hangs up the phone. She sees Skeeter's phone number taped to the wall. Aibileen's breath becomes heavy. Anger wells inside her. She picks up the phone again and begins to dial.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NEXT NIGHT - DUSK Wearing a black scarf over her hair and clutching her red satchel, Skeeter approaches a small, one-story wood structure. White paint peels, hydrangeas fill the yard. Skeeter spies an old pickup truck parked on the side of Aibileen's house, completely covered in years of dust. Skeeter checks over her shoulder several times. The porch steps creak under her big feet. Aibileen quickly opens the door and waves her inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen wears the same yellow dress she wore in the first scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I parked way up on State Street and caught a cab here like you asked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Got dropped two streets over? Skeeter nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen, I now know it's against the law for us to meet like this. Skeeter stares Aibileen up and down. Aibileen self- consciously flattens our her dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've never seen you out of uniform before. You look nice, Aibileen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Aibileen motions for Skeeter to sit on a narrow sofa behind a coffee table covered in hand-tatted lace. A tray holds a teapot, two cups that don't match and cookies resting on folded napkins. As Aibileen pours the tea, her hand shakes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. I've never had a white person in my house before. Skeeter sips her tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've never been in a colored person's home before. I think we're both doing great. This tea is really nice. Aibileen watches as Skeeter takes a bite of the cookie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Skeeter, What if...What if you don't like what I got to say? About white peoples?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...this isn't about my opinion. It doesn't matter how I feel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You gone have to change my name. Mine, Miss Leefolt's, everbody's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody? So, you know other maids who might be interested? Aibileen is quiet for a moment. She shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It gone be hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about Minny?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny got her some stories, sho nuff. But, she ain't real keen on talking to white peoples right now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We continue with the interview seen on page one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does it feel like, to raise a white child when your own child's at home, being...looked after by somebody else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It feel...Uh. Aibileen glances up to the framed picture of Treelore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that your son?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am. He dead two years now. Got run over at the lumber yard. Lungs were crushed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so sorry. That's horrible. And, Aibileen, you don't have to call me "ma'am." Not here anyway. Aibileen nods. Skeeter stares at her list of questions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want to talk about the bathroom? Or, about Elizab--Miss Leefolt? Anything about the way she pays you? Has she ever yelled at you in front of Mae Mobley? Aibileen shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, I- Aibileen covers her mouth with her hand. Skeeter becomes disgusted with herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I am. She pulls out a stack of Miss Myrna letters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's just do a couple of Miss Myrna letters, and I'll run on...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought I might write my stories down and read them to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, sure I guess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It no different than writing down my prayers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't say your prayers aloud?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prayer like electricity. It keep life going. Writing it down make it more powerful. Lot a ailing, sick peoples in this town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't get a chance to pray for Treelore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God took him fast `cause he didn't want to argue with me. He was just twenty-four years old. The best part of a person's life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Aibileen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he'd like we's doing this. He always said we gone have a writer in the family one day...After my prayers last night, I got some stories down too. Skeeter nods. Aibileen opens her notebook and reads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My first white baby to ever look after was named Alton Carrington Speers. It was 1938, and I'd just turned fourteen years old. Daddy had left us, so I dropped out a school to help momma with the bills.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A congregation of three hundred stand singing lively with the large choir. Aibileen stands next to Yule May and is whispering in her ear. Yule suddenly leans back, shocked, shaking her head "no." Minny watches from two pews back. Her curiosity is peaked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Alton's momma died a lung disease. I loved that baby, and he loved me. That's when I learned I could make children feel proud of theyselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Stein sits at her desk reading Aibileen's stories.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Alton used to always be asking me how come I's black...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It just ate him up, so one time I told him it cause I drank too much coffee. Oh, law, you should a seen his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Skeeter laughs as she writes down Aibileen's story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is great. You have no idea how much I appreciate this...But I just have to ask. What changed your mind?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Hilly Holbrook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hilly stands at a podium banging a gavel. The pleats of her navy blue sailor's number fan out like an accordion. A room full of JUNIOR LEAGUE MEMBERS sits up and quiets down. Half the girls are pregnant and most all drink TAB and are smoking. Skeeter sits in the back next to Elizabeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're running behind on our "coat drive," girls. So hurry up and clean out those closets...But our Christmas Benefit, however, is right on schedule as y'all have already filled all our baked goods raffle slots. The girls applaud, turning to each other with praise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Y'all think we can put a dent in the African Children's hunger this year? More applause. Those who aren't pregnant, stand. Hilly beams. Elizabeth nudges Skeeter out of her chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now for some exciting news...I wanted y'all to be the first to know...My William is seeking election to the State Senate this November! Now, even the pregnant women stand. Elizabeth grabs Skeeter's arm and pulls herself up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's runnin' on a platform of health. Protecting our children. Protecting our way of life. So, I, with William, have drafted The Home Health Sanitation Initiative. This sets off a room of whispers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter, when can we expect to see the initiative in the newsletter? I gave it to you a month ago. Everyone turns to Skeeter. Elizabeth panics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gave that to you myself!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ah...Well, I- HILLY Would you please stand, Skeeter? As Skeeter rises, several women shake their heads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll have it in there soon. Skeeter glances at the initiative tucked in her satchel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter turns a corner and sees Hilly leaning on her car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hilly? Do you need a ride? Hilly shakes her head with little emotion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry about the newsletter. Hilly nods. A soft smile begins to form.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With Momma being sick and- Hilly erupts with excitement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's coming! Oh, Skeeter, he's definitely coming this time. This Saturday night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Hilly, he's cancelled twice before. Maybe it's a sign.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you dare say that!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know I won't be his type. Hilly grabs Skeeter by the shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's your time, Skeeter. And damnit, I'm not going to let you miss this just because your mother convinced you you're not good enough for somebody like him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny is again wearing her maid's uniform. She puts two plates of food down on the kitchen table. She sits next to her daughter, SUGAR, 15. Sugar wears a brand-spanking-new maids's uniform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eat up, Girl. Miss Woodra's like to not feed ya on try-out day. Sugar takes a bite of toast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I still say you're too young to be waitin' on white peoples...Now, Sugar, I want you to listen to me, and you listen to me good. Minny grabs Sugar's face and looks her right in the eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These are the rules for working in a white lady's house. Sugar jerks her face away and sticks her lip out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rule Number One: Don't you ever let White Lady find you sittin' on her toilet. Sugar nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Number Two: You keep your nose out of White Lady's problems, and don't cry to her with yours. White people ain't your friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny steps off a bus and walks down an old country road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Number Three: When you're cooking white food, taste it with a different spoon. They see you put the tasting spoon back in the pot, might as well throw it all out. Spoon, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny approaches the Foote estate. She stops just short of stairs leading up to the front porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Four: You use the same cup, same fork, same plate every day. Minny takes her first step on the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) (CONT'D) Five: Don't hit her kids. White people do they own spanking. Minny slowly raises her hand to knock on the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) (CONT'D) Six: No sass-mouthing! Minny knocks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Number six, Minny. Number six. The door flies open. Celia Foote answers. She's covered in tight pink clothes. Flour covers her face and hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey there! I'm Celia Rae Foote. Aibileen said you'd be on time. Minny looks down disapprovingly to Celia's bare feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I get you a cold Coca-Cola?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, thank you. I'm Minny Jackson... You...cooking something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of those upsidedown cakes from the magazine. It ain't workin' out too good. Come on in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny enters behind Celia gawking at the flour massacre.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What in the hell- Minny catches herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tuck it in, Minny. Tuck it in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess I have some learnin' to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sure do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny and Celia enter a huge dining room. Minny gawks at a dusty mahogany table surrounded by twelve chairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Johnny's momma wouldn't let me decorate a thing. If I had my way, this house would have wall to wall white carpet with gold trim and none of this old stuff. Minny spies a framed battle-worn Confederate flag complete with bullet holes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where you from? Celia lowers her head in shame...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sugar Ditch. It's near Memphis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know Sugar Ditch. My cousin live there. Celia changes the subject.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's go meet Oscar! Celia grabs Minny's hand. Annoyed, Minny pulls it away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny stands at the base of a massive, stuffed Grizzly bear. It clears the twelve-foot ceiling by an inch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Johnny's granddaddy shot him up in Montana back in 1910 with Teddy Roosevelt. Celia points to fifteen guns mounted behind Oscar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We got five bedrooms and bathrooms here in the main house. The pool house has two more beds and baths.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you gone have some chillins, start fillin' up all these beds? Celia swallows hard. She places her hand on her stomach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm pregnant now. Minny steps back and surveys Celia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gone be eatin' for two. Double the cookin'. Celia slumps her shoulders as she looks around the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know it's an awful lot to do. Five other maids have already turned me down...Can I at least give you some bus money?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you hear me say I don't wanna clean this house?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? So...You'll do it?! Before Minny can nod. Celia throws her arms around her. Minny backs away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No huggin', now. No huggin'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. This is my first time hiring a maid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We got to talk about some things first. I work Sunday through Friday. Celia bites her pinky nail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't come at all on weekends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. What time you want me here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After eight, and you have to leave at four.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Now what your husband say you can pay? Celia looks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Johnny doesn't know I'm bringing in help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what's Mr. Johnny gone do if he comes home and finds a colored woman up in his kitchen?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not that I'd be fibbing. I just want him to think I can do this on my own...I need some help `til I get the hang of it. I need a maid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A course you do. Last one done got shot in the head. Minny sniffs the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Celia, I think you done burned up yo cake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Celia grabs a rag off the sink and jerks the cake out of the oven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oww! Dawgonit! She drops the burnt cake on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't use no wet towel on a hot pan. Minny grabs a dry towel and picks up the cake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll take this burnt up cake with me so Mister Johnny don't see it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEEFOLT HOME - MAE MOBLEY'S ROOM - MORNING Aibileen removes Mae Mobley's wet cloth diaper on a changing table. Mae Mobley's behind is covered with inflamed diaper rash. Aibileen shakes her head. Elizabeth enters the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm off, Aibileen. Don't forget Raleigh wants pot roast tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am. Aibileen's eyes narrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AIBILEEN'S HOME - KITCHEN - LATER THAT NIGHT Skeeter works with a typewriter now. Aibileen, more casually dressed than before, waits for Skeeter to finish typing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I reckon I'm ready...to talk about Miss Leefolt now. Skeeter stops typing and looks up. She nods.
direction.name: direction
