direction.raw_text: Baby girl don't get her diaper changed `til I get there in the morning. That's `bout ten hours she gots to sit in her mess. I be so worried about her on my day off. I always come in an hour early on Mondays.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlotte sits at a table sorting through mail as Skeeter enters and grabs an apple
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Miss Leefolt pregnant again, too. And, law, I pray this child turn out good. It a lonely road if a momma don't think theys child is pretty. Charlotte glances down disapprovingly at the dingy, huarache shoes on Skeeter's feet. Skeeter heads for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you going, Skeeter? Skeeter turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bible study.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On a Saturday night?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Momma, God doesn't care what day of the week it is. Skeeter walks out the back door as Charlotte shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hilly, Elizabeth and Jolene French stand with Hilly's contractor. He unrolls a set of bathroom plans. Hilly and Elizabeth look to Jolene and nod approvingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter's typing slows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Leefolt be spending so much time keeping up with the society ladies, she done forgot the child she got now. Just then Minny barges through the kitchen back door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen! Minny stops cold in her tracks at the sight of Skeeter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yule May told me what y'all up to. Aibileen nods. Minny's face hardens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Medgar Evers live five minutes away. They blew up his carport last night. For talking! Minny scowls at Skeeter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What makes you think colored people need your help? You white. Why you care?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We all working for the same thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe you just want to get her in trouble. Skeeter is petrified. Her face reddens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to show her perspective...so people might understand what it's like from your side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well it's a real Fourth of July picnic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's what we dream a doing all weekend long, get back in they house to polish the silver. And we just love not getting minimum wage or Social Security.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, Minny. Maybe things might
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What law's gonna say you gotta be nice to your maid? And another thing, I don't want my children going to school with white kids. And I don't care a thing about votin.' Only thing black mens get elected to is Deacon of the church.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't have to do this, Minny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You damn right I don't! You two givin' me the heart palpitations. Minny storms out the back door. Skeeter looks like she might get sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that was a good mood. Minny immediately storms back in the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right...I'm gone do it. I just want to make sure you know this ain't no game we're playing here. Skeeter nods, trembling as Minny slides a chair in the middle of the kitchen and sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slide your chair out from under that table and face me. I want to see you square on at all times. Still trembling, Skeeter slides her chair from the table and just sits there staring at Minny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I's got to come up with your questions, too?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's begin...begin with...with where you were born. Aibileen grabs her notebook and begins writing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Belzoni, Mississippi on my great- auntie's sofa. Next!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny talks a mile a minute. Aibileen continues writing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Once Minny got to talking `bout food, she liked to never stop...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I put the green beans in first, then I go on and get the pork chops going cause, mmm-mmm, I like my chops hot out the pan. Just as Aibileen fills the first notebook, Skeeter hands her another from her satchel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) But when she got to talking about the white ladies, it took all night...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The first signs of morning sun filter into the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Oh, Minny, I'm gone give you a week paid vacation." Now, I ain't had no paid vacation in my life. A week later, I come back and they'd moved to Mobile. "Miss Lazy Fingers" scared I'd find a new job before she moved... Minny spins around to Aibileen with sudden realization...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We gots to get more maids! Minny stands. Skeeter's eyes widen with hope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, but it hard, Minny. Mind racing, Minny flies out the door without a word. Aibileen turns to Skeeter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You gone and done it now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Stein discusses Aibileen and Minny's stories with Skeeter on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like this "Sarah Ross." She can kvetch but not complain too much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - PANTRY Skeeter nods rapidly as if she knows what "kvetch" means.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And this "Bertha"...she's got chutzpah. I'll give her that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So...you liked it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eugenia, Martin Luther King just invited the country to march with him in D.C. this August. This many negroes and whites haven't worked together since "Gone with the Wind."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does this mean you'll publish it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never said that. My advice is to write it fast before this civil rights thing blows over. I need it by New Year's, and don't send me anything more until you have twelve maids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twelve?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At least.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny, Aibileen and Skeeter sit at the kitchen table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen and I done asked everbody we know. Thirty-one maids. Everbody too scared, think we crazy...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then we might as well stop!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got plenty a stories, Miss Skeeter. Just write`em down and invent a maid that said it. We already making up everbody's name. Make up the maids, too. Skeeter jumps up from her chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can't do that! Aibileen and Minny lean back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean...I would never do that. It wouldn't be real. It's wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't give up on us, Miss Skeeter. Skeeter softens and sits back down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. Thank you both for trying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter delivers the "Miss Myrna" columns to the receptionist, who hands her back a paycheck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Celia and Minny stand at a fried chicken assembly line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What can you cook? Minny dips pieces chicken in an egg wash, then drops them in a paper bag. A puff of flour rises out of the bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can cook corn pone, boil potatoes, and do grits. Minny bursts out laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We didn't have electric current where I was raised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I reckon if there's anything you ought to know `bout cooking... Minny holds up a can of Crisco.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's this. The most important invention since they put mayonnaise in a jar. You don't even know the things you can do with this here can. Celia peers into the skillet as Minny spoons out a mound of Crisco.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How pretty. Looks like frosting. Minny rolls her eyes and hands Celia the bag of Chicken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shake that. Celia starts shaking the bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is fun!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny sits down at the table with a plate of chicken. Celia sits down next to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks so good! I'm starved. Aggravated, Minny stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You supposed to eat in the dining room, Miss Celia. That how it works. Minny grabs Celia's plate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here, I'll take your plate in the dinin' room for ya. Want tea?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm fine right here, Minny. Minny sits back down with a sigh. Celia touches her arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm real grateful you're here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Celia, you got a lot more to be grateful for than me. A car is heard pulling up in the driveway. Minny panics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mister Johnny?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, no! Hide! Minny slides down underneath the kitchen table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh...It's just the florist. Johnny must have sent me flowers. Minny pulls herself up off the floor. She's mad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Celia, I ain't playin' around no more! He gone catch me here and shoot me dead right here on this no- wax floor! You gots to tell him. Ain't he wondering how the cooking so good?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right. Maybe we ought to burn the chicken a little. The doorbell rings. Celia runs off to answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny don't burn chicken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter sits with a towel draped across her shoulders. Charlotte, now in an auburn wig, squirts mounds of goo from a pink tube onto Skeeter's hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is bound to work, Sweetie. It even smells expensive. She begins twisting Skeeter's hair into gooey spikes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I feel the hope in your fingers. Skeeter resembles a papier mache starfish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can you not know his last name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's William's cousin. That's all I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's just so sweet of Hilly. Charlotte takes a drag from her cigarette, then lifts up a silver machine complete with power cord and rubber hose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is that?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Shinolator! It cost eleven dollars. I'm a good mother. Charlotte puts a shower cap device on Skeeter's head and reads from the Shinolator manual.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "The Miracle Straitening Cap" must remain on the head for two hours."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two hours?! Charlotte flips a switch and takes another drag. The machine groans to life. Skeeter's cap inflates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll have Pascagoula bring you a magazine. Skeeter snatches her mother's cigarette and takes a drag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter sits under the Shinolator buried in a magazine. Pascagoula enters and sets down a glass of tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, Constantine. Do you think this dress is cute? Skeeter holds the magazine up to Pascagoula. Only now does she realize what she's said and done.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. Thanks, Pascagoula. Pascagoula nods and starts to walk away then turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew Constantine. She was a mighty fine woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Shinolator was a success. Skeeter's hair is straight, silky and beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holy shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've shrunk five inches. You'll be able to wear heels tonight. Charlotte looks down to the huarache shoes on Skeeter's feet and rushes to the closet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not leaving this house in those awful, Mexican, man shoes. Charlotte pulls out a dress and pair of heels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What time is he picking you up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's meeting me at Hilly's. Can I take the Cadillac?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We promised Carlton the Cadillac tonight. So, William's cousin will just have to come get you himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll take the truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's hooked to the motor grader.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll drive slow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter pulls away in a rusted 1941 Chevy farm truck with a huge motor grader attached. Charlotte runs next to the truck. Her wig is askew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't mope. Remember to smile! Skeeter floors it. Charlotte runs faster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And, don't sit like some squaw Indian. Cross! Your! Ankles! Skeeter leaves her mother in a cloud of dust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chunks of mud fly off the tires. The June sun has set the truck's interior at a stubborn 115 degrees. Skeeter has no choice but to lower her window. The Shinolator meets its match. A mangy, STRAY CAT suddenly jumps out in the road. When towing 10,000 pounds of farm equipment, slowing down quickly isn't an option.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A loud thud sounds out from the truck's grill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hilly, her husband, WILLIAM, and Skeeter's date, STUART WHITWORTH, drink high balls and eat cheese in the Holbrook parlor. Gold swag curtains hang on the windows. Balding and pudgy, only William's family money once made him a desirable bachelor. Stuart, on the other hand, is very handsome, the "Marlboro Man" in a well-tailored suit. Yule May (who we met earlier at church with Aibileen) now works for Hilly. She clears empty glasses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With your daddy's endorsement, I can win that Senate seat. Stuart feigns interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll talk to him. Ice slams against Stuart's teeth as he downs his drink. Hilly pats William's leg then turns with concern to a grandfather clock announcing half past the hour. The front door flies open. Skeeter enters completely out of breath and sweaty. Her HAIR HAS TRIPLED IN SIZE. She waves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey. As Hilly races toward Skeeter, William and Stuart stand. Stuart is as tall as he is handsome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boys, we'll be right back. Y'all talk about quarterbacks or something. Yule May, get Miss Skeeter a Coca Cola. Yule May runs off. Hilly pulls Skeeter down the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter sits on the toilet downing a Coca-Cola. Hilly twists the last of Skeeter's hair into giant rollers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter, you don't even have on lipstick! Skeeter dabs her armpits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was so goddamn awful. I hit a cat. Hilly sprays Final Net.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well...What do you think of him? Skeeter applies lipstick. Hilly removes the rollers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks handsome. Skeeter stands up and does a twirl for Hilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, give it to me. One to ten? Hilly sprays Skeeter with perfume and stands back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really?! Seven? Hilly nods, lets out a little squeal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey, you're beautiful. Just go on out there...you're gonna do great. It's your time, Skeeter. I just know it. Hilly hugs Skeeter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEE HOTEL - DINING ROOM - NIGHT Hilly, William, Stuart and Skeeter sit at a round table adorned with white linens, silver and fine china. The room buzzes with Jackson's elite all trying to be noticed as a JAZZ QUARTET plays softly in a corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: approaches. Stuart leans into Skeeter without making eye contact.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want a drink?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just water, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Double Old Kentucky straight...with a water back...Make that two backs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ?! So...you went to Alabama? Stuart nods. Hilly rolls her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Roll Tide." We still love him. Hilly pinches Stuart on the cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now you're in the oil business. Hilly says you're a rigsite leader.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The money's good. If that's what you really want to know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not what I- Skeeter and Hilly watch as Stuart's and William's eyes fix on the front of the restaurant. Celia and Johnny have entered. Celia wears a tight green dress and the reddest lipstick ever put in a tube.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't that your old boyfriend, Hilly? Johnny Foote? Hilly scowls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's his girl? Lord, she's hotter than Delta asphalt. Celia spots Hilly and gives a self-conscious wave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William! The Lieutenant Governor just walked in. Hilly jumps up and pulls William away. The waiter returns with Stuart's drink and the water backs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, what do you do with your time?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I write a...a domestic maintenance column for the Jackson Journal. Stuart smirks, taking a huge sip of his drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean housekeeping? Skeeter nods and grabs her water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus, I can't think of anything worse than reading a cleaning column. Except maybe writing one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEE HOTEL - LOBBY - SAME TIME Hilly and William finish shaking hands with the Lieutenant Governor. As he walks away, Hilly shouts out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'd love your support on election day! Celia and Johnny walk up. Hilly stiffens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hilly, you look lovely tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Johnny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William, have you ever met Celia? William steps forward and shakes Celia's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice to meet you. Hilly grabs the crook of William's arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sweetie, we need to go order our dinners. Celia musters up all the courage inside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hilly, did you ever get the messages that I've been calling you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I did not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I would love to help with the benefit. I have a lovely hand if you need invitations addressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Save the dates" were mailed weeks ago...You didn't get one? Celia shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mail's a lot slower way out there in the country, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, come on, before they run out of Trout Almondine. Hilly pulls William away. Johnny grabs Celia's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LEE HOTEL - DINING ROOM - CONTINUOUS STUART Sounds like a ploy to find a husband...becoming an expert on keeping house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you must be a genius. You figured out my whole scheme. Skeeter fumes as Hilly and William return and sit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What'd we miss?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't that what you women from Ole Miss major in? Professional husband hunting?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, but were you dropped on your head as an infant? Stuart blinks and then smiles, somewhat impressed. Desperate to change the subject, Hilly claps her hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who? Is? Hungry? Skeeter stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not me! A kiss from God couldn't turn this `frog' into a `prince.' Tables begin to stare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or you a `princess,' Sweetheart! As Skeeter walks away, she purposefully slides her purse into a glass of water, knocking it over into Stuart's lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hilly and William each have a section of newspaper in their face as Yule May clears breakfast dishes. Yule May lingers nervously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Run on, now, Yule May. Got a big crowd coming for Miss Leefolt's baby shower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Hilly, I would like to ask you and Mister William something. Hilly lowers her paper and nods. Yule May begins wrenching her hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My twin boys finished high school, both on the honor roll...My husband and I have been saving for years to send them to college.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay... Only now does William lower his paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are short seventy-five dollars on one of the tuitions. William stands up, kisses Hilly on the cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm late. Gotta go. William leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now...We're faced with having to choose. Which son gets to go...if we don't find all the money. Hilly draws in a deep breath as does Yule May.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you consider givin' us a loan? I'll...I'll work for free until it's paid off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not working for free, Yule May. That's paying off a debt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As a Christian, I'm going to do you a favor. Yule May's eyes widen as a hopeful smile forms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God doesn't give charity to those who are well and able. You need to come up with this money on your own. You'll thank me one day. Hilly raises the paper up to her face as Yule May exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Minny and Aibileen, in uniform, push carts side by side in the grocery store. The white shoppers are dressed casually. Other maids in the store (all required to be in uniform while shopping) keep quietly to themselves. White women smile and chat with one another as they meander down the aisles as if the black maids aren't even there. Minny suddenly spots Celia in the produce section. She pulls Aibileen close as they peer around the corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's her. Aibileen's mouth drops open at the sight of Celia's shorts and tight sweater. Celia is having trouble selecting produce.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lord, she's trying to shop. Celia walks up to a maid, grabs her, and pulls her to the tomatoes. The maid, clearly uncomfortable, selects a tomato, hands it to Celia, and scurries away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, Doll!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Celia just don't see `em. The lines. Not between us, Miss Hilly, nobody. Aibileen just nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What you so quiet for? I know you got a opinion `bout all this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You gone accuse me a philosophizing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ain't afraid a no philosophy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't believe in lines anymore. Lines is in our heads `cause people like Miss Hilly try to make us believe they there. Celia squeezes a canteloupe with another scared maid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, they there. I know. I get punished for crossing them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen and Minny continue their conversation while waiting with several other maids at a bus stop in front of the store.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lotta of folk think if you talk back to your husband, you crossed a line...need to be punished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know I ain't studying no line like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cause it ain't there. `Cept in Leroy's head. Lines between black and white ain't there either. Minny and Aibileen watch as Celia exits the store with her groceries and prances toward her car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, I ain't crossing no line if I tell Miss Celia she ain't good enough for Miss Hilly? Tell her she ain't in Miss Hilly's league?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All I'm saying is kindness don't have no boundaries. Just then, MYRLIE EVERS, 30, (Medgar Evers wife) approaches the bus stop with her three Children. SONS, 10 and 3, and a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Aibileen and Minny nod as the Evers walk past and sit on a bench.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Law, the Evers children have gotten so big!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cause they happy. Myrlie got her a good man...And you better not try to say they ain't no line between her Medgar and my Leroy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. You got me. A bus pulls up and the doors open. Minny, Aibileen and the other maids step aside to let the Evers family board first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen has come along to aid Yule May with Elizabeth's baby shower. A table is set in the middle of the yard covered in white linens and Hilly's best sliver. Hilly's son sits on her lap. The other girls' children wear bathing suits jumping noisily in and out of two plastic kiddy pools. Yule May clears cake plates while Aibileen removes crumbs with a sterling crumb scraper. Mae Mobley wanders up to the table. Her belly almost looks distended crammed inside last year's one piece.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mae Mo hungry, Momma. Elizabeth turns to Mae Mobley but never gets up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's always hungry. All the women laugh except for Skeeter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know she can hear you, Elizabeth? Elizabeth looks down to her plate. Aibileen sets down the scraper and kneels down to Mae Mobley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm on cut you some cake, Baby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen, we gave that scraper to Hilly and William for their wedding present. Chantilly!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It so pretty. Hilly begins bouncing William Jr. on her knee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen, are you enjoying your new bathroom over at Elizabeth's? Hilly nods with a tight smile and glances to the ground at Skeeter's red satchel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice to have your own, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Separate but equal. That's what Ross Barnett says, and you can't argue with the Governor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not in Mississippi. Birthplace of modern day government. Hilly narrows her eyes at Skeeter and turns to Aibileen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aibileen, did you know that me and Mister Holbrook arranged for that bathroom? Sent the boys over and the equipment, too. Hilly stays on Aibileen, waiting for her to say something. Skeeter fumes, hoping Aibileen doesn't say it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am...And I thank you. Hilly smiles and nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well...You. Are. Welcome. Hilly shoots Skeeter a last look. William Jr. leans into Hilly and hugs her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) One thing I got to say about Miss Hilly, she love her children. Always tellin' them they smart and beautiful. Can't go more than ten minutes without givin' one a kiss. Hilly kisses her son gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) (CONT'D) And, law, do they love her back. When she starts up on me, I just try and think a my sweet Treelore and how much he loved me. That kind a love makes me cry. Even when it going to Miss Hilly. Hilly again glances to the red satchel, staring quizzically at the worn booklet of The Jim Crow laws sticking out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yule May washes dishes as the women are heard saying their "good-byes" on the street. Skeeter slips into the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I get you something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, thanks... (HUSHED) Yule May, I wanted to talk to you. Yule May turns off the sink faucet making sure Hilly is still cackling out on the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know what you want to ask, Miss Skeeter. Aibileen and Minny already did. Yule May closes the kitchen door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm trying to get my boys off to college. It's worthwhile what y'all doing, but my boys are worth more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.C.) What do you "understand," Skeeter? Skeeter and Yule May turn to find Hilly standing in the swinging door leading into the dining room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah...Yule May was just telling me how excited she was that her boys were going to go to college.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that true, Yule May?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Ma'am. Skeeter notices that Hilly is holding the booklet of Jim Crow laws in her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you also ask Miss Skeeter if you could borrow money?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course not, Hilly! Hilly approaches Skeeter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter, I'm starting to think you're intentionally not putting my initiative in the newsletter. Eyes down, Yule May hurries out of the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all. I'm just so busy right now with Mom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter...I'm sorry about your mother. And I know you must be so worried. Hilly holds up the Jim Crow booklet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I'm worried about you. All this carrying on lately and now you're reading this stuff?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My dad had me get that for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean, around your friends is one thing...But, believe it or not, there are real racists in this town! If the wrong person caught you with this...you'd be in serious trouble. Skeeter snatches the booklet from Hilly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, Hilly! And thanks for going through my things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter types feverishly while smoking a cigarette. Keys type out: "Home Help Sanitation Initiative." Skeeter picks up Hilly's document and shakes her head. She types: Don't risk your children's and family's health!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yule May vacuums. She pulls the sofa away from the wall to clean beneath it. Noticing something on the floor, Yule May leans over. She rises holding a SMALL RUBY RING. Years of dust and hair blanket the pitiful gem set in ten karat gold. The vacuum seems to roar louder now. Yule May breathes heavily. She shoves the ring into her uniform pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Skeeter bangs away on her typewriter, Charlotte bursts into the room, stuck somewhere between panic and joy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't panic, but there's a very tall man named Stuart here for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a drunken asshole, Mother. You wouldn't like him. Charlotte pulls a sun dress out of Skeeter's closet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter, love and hate are two horns on the same goat. And, you need a goat!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter, Charlotte and Stuart sit in the living room. Pascagoula serves finger sandwiches. Stuart looks nice in khaki pants, a blue blazer and a red tie. His nose is pink from working in the sun. No one says a word. Finally...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stuart, would you like a cocktail? Skeeter shoots her mother a "What the..." look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Ma'am. Little too early.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ha! Charlotte moves on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's your last name, Stuart?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whitworth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hmm...Where are you from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Natchez.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really? Well, I know a Whitworth from Natchez...But he's a Senator up in Washington.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Ma'am. That's my daddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Senator Whitworth. That's my father. Charlotte's jaw drops to her string of pearls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really? Stuart nods. Charlotte stands, flustered yet joyful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well...tell him I said "Hello"...I'm going to go see if Pascagoula needs some help in the kitchen. Charlotte backs away behind Stuart's chair. She points at Skeeter violently, as if to say, DON'T MESS THIS UP!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skeeter and Stuart stand beneath an old Cypress tree as Charlotte peeps from an upstairs window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look. I know it was a few weeks back, but I came here to say I'm sorry for the way I acted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who sent you? William or Hilly?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neither. I was rude, and I've been thinking about it a lot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I haven't. So, just go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, look. I told Hilly I wasn't ready to go out on any date. I wasn't even close to ready. Stuart shoves his hands in his pockets like a boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was engaged last year. She ended it. Skeeter refuses to pity him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'd been dating since we were fifteen. You know how it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually, I don't. I've never dated anyone before. Stuart looks up and starts laughing loudly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well! That must be it then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've never met a woman that said exactly what she was thinking.
direction.name: direction

Some have towering tanks with chain pulls at the top, providing amusement to the procession of cars driving by. The Holbrook's station wagon sits in the driveway, doors still open with LUGGAGE tied to the roof. Two OLD BLACK MEN struggle to remove a toilet under William's supervision.

direction.raw_text: Y'all stay put. Let me find out what's going on. As the driver gets up, a WLBT-TV news truck whizzes by followed by a police motorcycle. Aibileen leans in the aisle and looks ahead. The driver returns. The young black man speaks up.

Told him he `bout to start farmin' too. But he bought it just for me. So I could get to work easy. He did. Skeeter closes her eyes for moment.
